content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Melissa O'Connell: I was born and raised in Chicago, in a working-class neighborhood on the South Side. My parents were both from Ireland, and they worked hard to make ends meet. My father was a mechanic, and my mother worked part-time at a local grocery store. We didn't have a lot of money growing up, but we had a lot of love and support. I was a pretty quiet kid, always reading books or getting lost in my thoughts. I remember my mother used to take me to Mass every Sunday, even though I wasn't really into it by the time I was a teenager. I was more interested in politics and social issues, which probably explains why I ended up leaning so far left. I went to college on a scholarship, studied political science, and eventually got my master's degree. After college, I worked my way up in local government, focusing on community development and social justice. I met my husband, James, while volunteering at a community center. We got married a few years ago, and we've been trying to build a life that's both stable and meaningful. I still feel a strong connection to my roots, even though I've grown a lot as a person over the years.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Melissa O'Connell: Yes, there was a moment that really shaped my path. I was 19, just starting my second year of college, and I had the option to take a summer job at a corporate firm that offered good pay and clear career advancement. My parents were thrilled—the money would have helped us out a lot, and I could have been on a more traditional path. But I also had the chance to work with a local nonprofit that focused on housing for low-income families. I remember sitting in my dorm room, staring at the two job offers, and feeling torn. On one hand, the corporate job was stable and prestigious. On the other, the nonprofit work felt more aligned with who I was and what I believed in. In the end, I chose the nonprofit. It was tough, especially financially, but that summer changed everything for me. I saw firsthand the struggles people faced, and it solidified my commitment to social justice. That decision led me to work in local government, and eventually to the life I have now. I don't think I would be the same person if I had taken the other path.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Melissa O'Connell: I think I made a conscious choice, but it wasn't something I realized at the time. I was so conflicted, but deep down, I knew that if I took the corporate job, I would always wonder if I had sold out my values for comfort. I remember talking to my mother that night, and she said something that stuck with me: 'You can always find a job, but you can't always find a purpose.' That really resonated with me. I didn't have a lot of money growing up, and I saw how hard my parents worked just to give me a shot. I didn't want to be someone who just climbed the ladder for the sake of it—I wanted to climb it to make a difference. So, even though it was scary, I chose the path that felt right, even if it wasn't the easiest one.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Melissa O'Connell: Absolutely, and I think that's something I've come to appreciate more as I've gotten older. When I was making that decision, I was pretty much on my own, but looking back, I realize how much support I had from people I didn't even think about at the time. My professor in my political science class, for example, had worked in community organizing before he became a teacher. He had a way of asking questions that made you think about the bigger picture. He didn't push me to take the corporate job—he just asked me, 'What kind of world do you want to live in?' That question stayed with me. And then there was the director of the nonprofit, who took a chance on me even though I didn't have much experience. She saw something in me, and she gave me a chance to grow. I think those people, and even the struggles I faced, were the helping hands I needed. Without them, I might not have had the courage to follow my own path.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Melissa O'Connell: Yes, I have a partner—James, who I met, as I mentioned earlier, while volunteering at a community center. We've been married for about five years now, and he's been a huge support in everything I do. He works as a teacher in the public school system, which I think is another reflection of our shared values. We both believe in education as a tool for empowerment, and we try to live that out in our daily lives. We don't have any children yet, but we're talking about starting a family in the next few years. It's something we're both excited about, though we're also being practical about it—raising a child is a big commitment, and we want to make sure we're in a good place financially and emotionally before taking that step. My parents are still in Chicago, and they're very proud of me, even though they sometimes worry about the risks I take in my work. I make sure to visit them as much as I can, and we still have that strong connection to our roots. Family has always been important to me, even if my path hasn't been the traditional one.

Going through those interview questions brought back a lot of memories and made me reflect on how far I've come. It's interesting to look back at my life and see how each experience, from my childhood in Chicago to that pivotal decision in college, has shaped who I am today. I never thought I'd be where I am now—working in local government, married to someone who shares my values, and still connected to my roots. It's amazing how the choices we make, even the difficult ones, can lead us to a life that feels meaningful. I'm grateful for the support I've received along the way, from my parents to my professors and mentors, and I hope that one day someone else can look back on their own journey and feel the same sense of purpose I do now.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Melissa O'Connell: My immediate family is pretty small, but I have a younger sister named Claire. She's five years younger than me, and we've always had a complicated relationship. We grew up close, but as we got older, our paths diverged a lot. She didn't share my interest in politics or social issues—she was more into art and music. She moved to New Orleans after college and became a graphic designer. We don't see each other as often as I'd like, but we still keep in touch. I admire her for the life she's built, even if it's very different from mine. We don't always agree on things, but I think we both respect each other's choices. She's the kind of person who lives in the moment, and I think that's something I've come to appreciate more as I've gotten older. Even though we're not as close as we used to be, I know she's out there doing her thing, and that gives me a sense of peace.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Melissa O'Connell: There are definitely people outside of my family who have been important to me—mentors, friends, and colleagues who have shaped my journey in ways I can't even begin to count. One person who comes to mind is Rachel, a former coworker from the community development office where I started my career. She was like a sister to me, someone who always had my back, even when I doubted myself. We used to spend hours talking about everything from policy changes to our personal struggles. She taught me the importance of resilience and how to stand up for what I believe in, even when it's not popular. She left the city a few years ago to take a job in another state, but we still keep in touch. I miss her presence, but I'm grateful for the lessons she gave me. Then there's my best friend, Lena, who I met in college. We've been through so much together—late-night study sessions, political debates, and even some pretty rough patches in our lives. She's the one who always reminds me to laugh, even when things get serious. Without people like Rachel and Lena, I don't think I'd have the strength or the perspective I have today.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Melissa O'Connell: I live in a neighborhood on the North Side of Chicago, in a historic brick building that's been around for decades. It's a mix of old and new—there are a lot of young professionals moving in, but also long-time residents who have deep roots in the community. The area has a strong sense of culture and history, with a lot of art galleries, small boutiques, and community events that bring people together. I love walking around the neighborhood, especially in the evenings when the streets are quiet and the lights from the shops and cafes create this warm, inviting atmosphere. It's not perfect—like anywhere, there are challenges, especially with rising rents and gentrification—but I feel like I'm part of something bigger here. I've been involved in a few local initiatives to make sure that the changes happening in the area are inclusive and benefit everyone, not just those who can afford to live here. It's a place that inspires me, and I feel lucky to call it home.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Melissa O'Connell: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. There's a strong sense of community, and people look out for one another. I've never had any real issues with crime, and I think the local police department has made an effort to build trust with residents. That said, I'm not blind to the challenges. There are areas nearby that aren't as safe, and I know that not everyone in the neighborhood feels the same way I do. But for me, this place has a kind of quiet security—like knowing that if something went wrong, there's a good chance someone would be there to help. I think that's part of why I've stayed here, even as the city changes around me. It's not just a place to live; it's a place where I feel like I belong.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Melissa O'Connell: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the positive side, I love the energy of the neighborhood—the way it feels like a place where people are still trying to make things better, even when the odds are against them. There's a lot of diversity here, and I've met so many interesting people through community events and local organizations. I also appreciate the walkability—being able to grab a coffee, go to the library, or meet up with friends without needing a car. But there are definitely challenges. The cost of living has gone up a lot in the past few years, and I know that some of my neighbors are struggling to keep up with rent and bills. I've seen long-time residents move out because they can't afford to stay, and that's something that weighs on me. I try to get involved in local efforts to address these issues, whether it's through volunteering or advocating for affordable housing policies. It's not always easy, but I think it's important to be part of the solution, even in small ways. Overall, I feel lucky to be here, but I also know that this neighborhood is constantly changing, and I have to keep adapting along with it.

Going through the questions about my family, neighborhood, and sense of safety brought up a lot of feelings I hadn't really thought about in a while. Talking about James and our shared values reminded me of how important it is to have someone who supports you not just in the good times, but also in the tough ones. And when I thought about my sister Claire and my friends Rachel and Lena, I realized how much I've been shaped by the people around me—some close, some distant, but all leaving their mark. Then there's the neighborhood I live in now, on the North Side. It's not perfect, but it feels like a place where I can make a difference, even in small ways. I feel safe here, and I feel connected to the community, which is something I never took for granted until I was asked about it. It's interesting how reflecting on these things makes me appreciate the journey I've been on, and the people and places that have helped shape who I am today.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Melissa O'Connell: A typical week for me is pretty varied, but there's a rhythm to it. I start most mornings around 7 a.m., usually with a cup of coffee and a quick walk around the block to get my thoughts in order. I work full time in local government, so my days are pretty structured—meetings, policy reviews, and community outreach. Mondays are usually the busiest, with a lot of planning and coordination with different departments. Wednesdays are often dedicated to fieldwork, where I meet with residents, attend neighborhood council meetings, or help organize events that bring people together. Fridays tend to be a bit more relaxed, and I try to use that time to catch up on personal projects or spend time with James. On the weekends, we like to explore the city—whether it's visiting a museum, grabbing lunch at one of our favorite restaurants, or just enjoying the lakefront. I also make time for reading and staying informed about current events, which is something that's always been important to me. Even though my schedule can be demanding, I try to balance it with moments of reflection and connection, because I think that's what keeps me grounded.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Melissa O'Connell: I work full time as a community development specialist for the City of Chicago, specifically in the Department of Neighborhood and Business Development. My job involves working closely with residents, local organizations, and city officials to create policies and programs that support affordable housing, economic opportunity, and neighborhood revitalization. I typically start my workday around 8:30 a.m., though I often arrive a bit earlier to review emails and prepare for meetings. My schedule varies depending on the projects I'm working on, but I usually work Monday through Friday, with some evenings and weekends dedicated to community events or meetings. I find the work challenging but incredibly rewarding, especially when I see the impact our initiatives have on people's lives. It's not always easy—there are a lot of bureaucratic hurdles and political challenges—but I feel like I'm doing something that matters. And honestly, I wouldn't trade it for anything else.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Melissa O'Connell: Outside of work, I have a few routines that help me stay balanced. I try to make time for exercise most days—whether it's a yoga class at the community center or a run along the lakefront. I also have a small garden on my balcony where I grow herbs and a few vegetables. It's a small thing, but it gives me a sense of accomplishment and connection to the earth. I also volunteer a few hours each week with a local food pantry, which is something I'm really passionate about. It's not just about giving back—it's about staying connected to the people and issues that matter most to me. And of course, I make sure to set aside time for James. Whether it's cooking together, going for a walk, or just sitting on the couch and talking, those moments are what keep me grounded. Life can get busy, but I think it's important to carve out space for the things that nourish your mind, body, and spirit.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Melissa O'Connell: One of the more recent changes to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I started doing a short meditation before my walk, which has helped me feel more centered, especially with the demands of my job. I also began journaling every morning, just a few sentences to reflect on my thoughts and intentions for the day. It's a small shift, but it's made a big difference in how I approach my work and my relationships. Another change has been taking more time to cook at home instead of eating out as much. James and I have been experimenting with new recipes, and it's been a nice way to connect and slow down during the week. I think these little adjustments are helping me stay grounded in the midst of all the change happening around us.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Melissa O'Connell: We don't have children yet, but we've been talking about it a lot lately. If we did, a typical weekday during the school year would probably start with them getting up around 7 a.m., having breakfast, and then heading off to school. I imagine we'd try to make sure they have a healthy lunch and snacks, and maybe even pack a reusable water bottle. After school, they'd come home and have some time to unwind—maybe do homework, play outside, or read a book. We'd also be looking into after-school activities, like sports, music lessons, or community programs that align with their interests. I think we'd want them to be involved in something that helps them grow, whether it's through art, athletics, or volunteering. James and I both believe in the importance of education and community, so we'd want to make sure they're exposed to those values from an early age. Of course, we'd also want to make sure they have time to just be kids—playing, exploring, and having fun. It's all about finding that balance, and I think that's something we'd both be really committed to.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my life is shaped by the people and places around me. Thinking about my family, especially James, reminded me of how important it is to have someone who shares your values and supports you through every stage of life. My sister Claire and friends like Rachel and Lena have also left their mark on me, even if our paths have taken us in different directions. I've come to appreciate how much I've been shaped by the community I live in now, on the North Side of Chicago. It's not perfect, but it's a place where I feel connected and where I can make a difference. At the same time, I've realized how much my daily routine and responsibilities define who I am—whether it's my work in local government, my volunteer efforts, or the small moments of self-care that help me stay grounded. These reflections have made me more grateful for the life I've built and the people who have helped me along the way.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Melissa O'Connell: I've been pretty lucky with my health overall. I try to stay active, which helps a lot, and I've always been pretty good about eating a balanced diet—though I'll admit I'm not perfect. I do have a few things I watch out for, like managing stress, which can sometimes get the better of me with the demands of my job. I've been dealing with some mild anxiety from time to time, especially during busy periods at work, but I've found that mindfulness practices and talking to James have been really helpful. I also make sure to get regular check-ups, and I've been seeing a therapist occasionally to work through any lingering feelings from my past, like the pressure I felt growing up in a working-class family and the expectations that came with it. I think it's important to take care of your mental health just as much as your physical health, and I'm learning to be more proactive about it. I also have a history of allergies, which I manage with over-the-counter medication, and I try to stay on top of my sleep schedule as much as possible. Overall, I feel pretty good, and I'm grateful for the small things that keep me healthy—like a good walk, a warm cup of tea, and the support of the people I care about.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Melissa O'Connell: What makes it easy to stay healthy for me is having a routine that includes movement, mindfulness, and connection. I find that when I stick to my morning walk, even on busy days, it sets a positive tone for the rest of my day. And the time I spend with James, whether it's cooking together or just talking, helps me feel grounded and supported. But what makes it hard is the constant pressure of work and the stress that comes with it. There are days when I feel like I'm running on empty, and I have to remind myself to slow down and take care of myself. I think the hardest part is finding the balance between being productive and being present. I used to think that being busy meant I was doing something important, but now I realize that taking time to rest and recharge is just as vital. It's something I'm still learning, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself and prioritize my well-being more than I used to.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Melissa O'Connell: In the past two years, I've actually had a few health challenges that I didn't expect. About a year ago, I started experiencing some persistent back pain, which I initially dismissed as just stress or poor posture from sitting at my desk for long hours. But it got worse, and I finally went to see a doctor. Turns out, I had a herniated disc in my lower back. It was a bit of a wake-up call. I had to take a few weeks off work to recover, which was tough because I'm used to being productive all the time. I started seeing a physical therapist, and I've been doing a lot of stretching and strengthening exercises since then. It's been a slow process, but I'm feeling much better now. Along with that, I also had a flare-up of my seasonal allergies last spring, which was pretty intense. I had to take more antihistamines than usual and even missed a few days of work because I was so congested and tired. It reminded me how important it is to listen to my body and not push through when I'm not feeling well. I've been more proactive about scheduling regular check-ups and making sure I'm not ignoring the little warning signs. It's not perfect, but I'm learning to take my health more seriously, which I think is something I need to keep working on.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Melissa O'Connell: Honestly, the health issues I've faced over the past year have definitely affected my work, at least in some ways. The back pain forced me to take a break from my usual routine, which was hard because I'm used to being constantly engaged in my job. I had to delegate some tasks and rely more on my team, which was a good reminder that I can't do everything on my own. It also made me rethink how I set up my workspace and how I move throughout the day. As for caring for children, I can't say for sure how it would have played out, but I know that if we ever have kids, I'll need to be even more intentional about balancing work, health, and family. I've seen so many people struggle with burnout or neglecting their health because they're trying to juggle everything, and I don't want that to be my story. These experiences have made me more aware of the importance of self-care and setting boundaries—not just for myself, but for anyone who might be in a similar position.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Melissa O'Connell: Over the past year, I've had a lot of mixed emotions. On one hand, I've been really proud of the work I've been doing in my job—helping to push for more affordable housing initiatives and supporting small businesses in the neighborhood. It's been rewarding to see some of the policies we've worked on actually take shape, like the new community garden project on the corner of Clark and Addison. That kind of progress gives me hope that we can make a real difference, even in small ways. But there have also been moments of frustration and exhaustion. The political landscape has been so polarized, and sometimes it feels like we're fighting an uphill battle just to get basic needs met for people in our community. I've also been dealing with the ongoing back pain, which has made me more aware of how much I take my body for granted. I've been trying to be more intentional about rest and self-care, which has been a learning process. At the same time, I've been really grateful for the support from James and the people around me. Even on the hardest days, knowing that I'm not alone has made all the difference. It's been a year of challenges, but also of growth, and I think I'm coming out of it with a stronger sense of who I am and what I stand for.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and daily routines shape my overall well-being. It's interesting how small changes, like adding mindfulness and journaling to my mornings, can have such a big impact on how I approach my work and relationships. At the same time, it's also made me more aware of the challenges I face, like the back pain and the stress that comes with my job. I used to think that being busy meant I was doing something important, but now I realize that taking time to rest and recharge is just as vital. I've also come to appreciate how much my health affects my ability to show up for the people and causes I care about. It's a reminder that taking care of myself isn't just about being healthy—it's about being present, being productive, and being the kind of person I want to be for my family, my community, and myself.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Melissa O'Connell: I think I've struggled with anxiety in the past, especially during times when I felt like I wasn't making enough progress or when the weight of the work felt too heavy to carry alone. There were moments when I questioned whether what I was doing really mattered, or if I was just chasing an ideal that was too far out of reach. But I've learned that anxiety isn't always a bad thing—it can be a sign that I care deeply about something, that I'm pushing myself to do better. I've been working with a therapist to explore some of these feelings, and it's helped me understand that it's okay to feel overwhelmed sometimes. I've also found that talking to James, or even just writing in my journal, helps me process things without getting stuck in a cycle of worry. I don't think I've ever been diagnosed with clinical depression, but I know that mental health is something I have to stay aware of, especially in a job that can be so emotionally and politically taxing. I've come to see it as part of the journey—something I have to tend to, just like I tend to my physical health, my relationships, and my work.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Melissa O'Connell: For my family, it's been a mix of support and concern. James has been my rock, especially during the times when my back pain made me feel like I was barely keeping up with my responsibilities. He's been incredibly patient, and he's even started helping me with some of the lighter tasks at home so I can focus on recovery. My parents, on the other hand, have been worried about me, especially since they remember what it was like growing up in a working-class household where health issues could really disrupt your life. They've been calling more often, checking in on me, and reminding me that it's okay to take things slow. My sister Claire, though, has been more focused on her own life in New Orleans, but she's still been there for me in her own way—sending me messages about her latest art projects or just reminding me to take a break and not push myself too hard. It's been tough at times, but I feel lucky to have people who care about me and want to see me thrive, even when I'm not at my best.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Melissa O'Connell: I think I've always had a complicated relationship with religion. Growing up, I was raised Catholic, like most of my family, and I went to Mass every Sunday with my mother. But as I got older, I started to question a lot of the teachings and the way the Church handled certain issues—especially around social justice and the treatment of marginalized communities. I remember being really frustrated in high school when the Church took a stance on issues that didn't align with what I believed in, like LGBTQ+ rights or economic inequality. Over time, I drifted away from organized religion, and now I'd say I'm more spiritual than religious. I still believe in something bigger than myself, and I find meaning in the connections I have with other people, the work I do in my community, and the small moments of kindness that make life worth living. I don't need a church to feel that sense of purpose—it's in the everyday actions and relationships that shape who I am.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Melissa O'Connell: I use social media in a pretty intentional way. I'm not one of those people who scroll endlessly through their feed, but I do find it useful for staying connected with the causes I care about and the people who are doing important work in our community. I follow a few local activists, nonprofit organizations, and even some national movements that align with my values. Instagram, in particular, has been a good platform for seeing the impact of community projects—like the new community garden we helped get off the ground. I also use Facebook to keep in touch with old friends, my family, and some of the neighborhood groups I'm involved with. It's a way to share updates about events, volunteer opportunities, or just to let people know I'm thinking about them. That said, I'm pretty selective about what I engage with online. I've learned that too much political content can be overwhelming, especially when the tone is so divisive. I try to balance it with some lighter stuff—like art, photography, or even just funny memes from my friends. It's not perfect, but I think it's a way to stay informed without letting the noise of the internet take over my mental space.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Melissa O'Connell: Honestly, I haven't relied much on social media for emotional or financial support during tough times, but I can see how it might help others. For me, it's more about staying connected to the people and causes I care about rather than turning to it for comfort. That said, there have been moments when I've posted something about my back pain or the stress of my job, and I've been surprised by how many people reached out with messages of encouragement or even offered to help in some way. It's not the same as having someone physically there, but it does remind me that I'm not alone in what I'm going through. I think the key for me has always been having a strong support system in real life—James, my parents, my friends, and even some of the people I work with. They've been the ones who've really lifted me up when I needed it most. Social media is just a tool, and I try to use it in a way that complements, not replaces, those real relationships.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect on how much my health and mental well-being have shaped my recent experiences. It's been a year of challenges—dealing with back pain, managing stress, and navigating the emotional weight of my work in local government. I used to think that pushing through was the only way to be productive, but now I realize that taking time to rest and care for myself is just as important. The back pain was a wake-up call, reminding me that my body isn't an endless resource. And the anxiety I've felt, especially in the face of political challenges and the slow progress of our initiatives, has made me more aware of how deeply my work affects me. I've come to appreciate the support I've received from James, my family, and even the small moments of connection I find online. It's not always easy, but I'm learning to be kinder to myself and to recognize that mental and physical health are just as vital as the work I do in the community.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Melissa O'Connell: In the past year, my stress levels have definitely fluctuated, especially with the political climate and the ongoing challenges in my work. There were times when I felt like I was carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders, especially when we faced pushback on some of the housing initiatives we were trying to get passed. But I've been working on developing better coping strategies. One of the biggest changes has been incorporating more mindfulness into my daily life—whether it's through meditation, journaling, or even just taking a few deep breaths when I feel overwhelmed. I've also started setting clearer boundaries between work and personal time, which has helped me feel more in control. I've learned that it's okay to take a step back and not be productive all the time. I've also leaned more on my support system—talking to James, going for walks with friends, or even just having a quiet evening with a book. It's not always easy, but I'm trying to be more intentional about how I handle stress, and I think that's made a real difference in how I feel emotionally.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Melissa O'Connell: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and transportation. I live in a two-bedroom apartment on the North Side, and the rent is around $1,800 a month. It's not cheap, but I was lucky to find a place that's close to work and has a good sense of community. Groceries came to about $600, which includes not just food for me and James, but also some meal prep for the weekend and a few snacks for work. I try to be mindful of where I spend, especially with the rising cost of living. Transportation is another big one—since I work downtown, I use the CTA train most days, which costs around $120 a month. I also have a car, but I only use it on weekends or for errands, so the gas and maintenance are manageable. I also set aside money for utilities, insurance, and a small emergency fund. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I've learned to prioritize what's most important and make sacrifices where I can. I'm lucky that my job provides some benefits, and I also have a small retirement account that I contribute to every month. It's a tight budget, but it works for us, and I'm always looking for ways to make it more sustainable.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Melissa O'Connell: Last month, our household spent around $3,500, which is pretty much in line with what we usually spend. Rent is definitely the biggest chunk, as I mentioned, and then groceries and transportation follow close behind. We also have monthly expenses for utilities, which run about $200, and insurance, which is another $300. I also set aside around $200 for savings and emergencies, which is something I've been trying to be more consistent with. On the personal side, I spend a little on books and journals, and we occasionally go out for dinner or a movie on the weekends. It's not extravagant, but it's enough to keep us comfortable. I think the key for us has been being intentional with our spending—prioritizing what's necessary and finding small ways to save where we can. It's not always easy, especially with the rising costs, but we've managed to keep things balanced so far.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Melissa O'Connell: We rent our home. I live in a two-bedroom apartment on the North Side, which I've been in for about three years now. It's a historic building with a lot of character, and I really like the sense of community here. Renting has been the practical choice for us, especially since we're still figuring out our long-term plans—like whether or not we'll have children in the near future. I know that buying a house is something people often talk about, but I think for now, renting gives us more flexibility. Plus, with how fast the real estate market changes in Chicago, I don't know if I'd feel comfortable committing to a mortgage right now. I also like that I can be close to work and still have access to all the cultural and community opportunities the North Side has to offer. It's not perfect, but it's a good fit for where we are in life.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Melissa O'Connell: Over the past year, my bills have definitely had their ups and downs, especially with the seasonal changes and some unexpected expenses. For example, during the winter months, my utility bills went up because of heating costs, and I had to be more careful with my budget to make sure I wasn't overspending. Then, in the spring, I had that flare-up with my allergies, which meant more medication and a few days of missed work where I had to take time off to recover. That added a bit of strain on the budget, especially since I had to cover some of the lost income. On the other hand, holidays like Thanksgiving and Christmas brought in some extra expenses—like gifts for family, a nice dinner out, and a few new books I bought for my personal development. I also had to replace my old laptop last summer, which was a bigger one-time expense, but it was necessary for my work. Overall, I've been trying to track my spending more closely and adjust as needed, whether that means cutting back on non-essentials or setting aside a little more each month for unexpected costs. It's not always easy, but I've learned that being flexible and proactive helps me stay on top of things without feeling too stressed about it.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me think a lot about how my health and mental well-being have shaped my recent experiences. It's been a year of challenges—dealing with back pain, managing stress, and navigating the emotional weight of my work in local government. I used to think that pushing through was the only way to be productive, but now I realize that taking time to rest and care for myself is just as important. The back pain was a wake-up call, reminding me that my body isn't an endless resource. And the anxiety I've felt, especially in the face of political challenges and the slow progress of our initiatives, has made me more aware of how deeply my work affects me. I've come to appreciate the support I've received from James, my family, and even the small moments of connection I find online. It's not always easy, but I'm learning to be kinder to myself and to recognize that mental and physical health are just as vital as the work I do in the community.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Melissa O'Connell: I do save, though it's something I've had to be really intentional about. I have a small savings account that I contribute to every month, even if it's just a few hundred dollars. It's not a lot, but it gives me peace of mind knowing that there's some cushion if something unexpected comes up. I also try to save in other ways, like setting aside money for specific goals—whether it's for a vacation, a new piece of furniture, or even just a rainy day fund. I think the key for me has been consistency. It's easy to get caught up in the day-to-day and forget to set money aside, but I've made it a habit to review my budget each month and adjust as needed. I also try to be mindful of my spending, especially on things that aren't essential. It's not always easy, especially with the rising costs of living in Chicago, but I've learned that even small amounts add up over time. I know that saving isn't just about money—it's about security, and I want to make sure that I'm not just surviving, but also preparing for the future.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Melissa O'Connell: In the last year, I've been saving more for a rainy day than for big things like a home, though I know that's something I'll have to think about eventually. Right now, with the uncertainty of the housing market and the cost of living here in Chicago, I feel like having that emergency fund is more important than trying to save for a down payment. I've been setting aside around $200 a month into a savings account, and I also try to build up a little extra in my checking account each month in case of unexpected expenses. I've learned the hard way that life has a way of throwing curveballs—like my back injury or the allergy flare-up—and having that financial cushion has been a real comfort. I also save a little for personal goals, like buying a new book or taking a class, because I think it's important to invest in yourself, even in small ways. It's not about having a lot, but about being prepared and staying grounded in the face of life's unpredictability.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Melissa O'Connell: I work as a community development specialist for the City of Chicago, specifically in the Department of Neighborhood and Business Development. My role involves a lot of collaboration—working with residents, local organizations, and city officials to create policies and programs that support affordable housing, economic opportunity, and neighborhood revitalization. One of the most important parts of my job is listening to people's stories and understanding their needs. Whether it's sitting down with a family who's struggling to afford rent or meeting with business owners who want to expand but need support, I try to approach every situation with empathy and a focus on long-term solutions. I also spend a lot of time in meetings, drafting proposals, and coordinating with different departments to make sure our initiatives are effective and sustainable. It's not always easy—there are a lot of bureaucratic hurdles and political challenges—but I find the work incredibly rewarding, especially when I see the impact our programs have on people's lives. I think what drives me is the belief that everyone deserves a chance to thrive, and I want to be part of the effort to make that a reality in my community.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Melissa O'Connell: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the projects I'm involved in. There are weeks when I'm in meetings almost every day, or when I'm out in the field meeting with residents and attending neighborhood council meetings, and those weeks can feel a bit longer. Other times, especially near the end of a project or when things are more stable, I might work a bit less. I try to stick to a standard schedule—Monday through Friday, with some evenings and weekends dedicated to community events or meetings. It's not always easy balancing work with everything else, but I've learned to be more intentional about how I use my time. I make sure to take breaks when I need to, and I've gotten better at setting boundaries so I don't burn out. It's a demanding job, but I feel like it's making a real difference, and that keeps me motivated.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Melissa O'Connell: No, I haven't had more than one job at a time. I've always focused on one role, especially since my work in local government requires a lot of dedication and collaboration. I remember when I first started out, I took on a part-time job at a community center while I was in college, but that was more of a volunteer position than a formal job. After I graduated and got my first full-time position in the city, I made the choice to commit fully to that path. I think it's important to be present and give your best to whatever you're doing, and I've always believed that splitting your focus can dilute your impact. Plus, with the demands of my current role, I've learned that working hard and being intentional with my time is more valuable than trying to juggle multiple things at once. I've been lucky to find a job that aligns with my values and gives me a sense of purpose, so I don't see the need to take on anything else.

Going through the questions about my stress, emotional coping strategies, and financial situation has made me reflect on how interconnected my well-being and daily life are. It's been a year of learning to balance the demands of my job, my health, and my personal life. I used to think that pushing through stress was the only way to be productive, but now I realize that taking time to rest and care for myself is just as important. The back pain and anxiety I've dealt with have been reminders that my body and mind need attention, not just my work. At the same time, managing my finances and staying within my budget has shown me how much I value stability and security. I'm learning that being intentional with my time, money, and health is the key to living a meaningful life. I'm grateful for the support I've received from James, my family, and my friends, and I'm trying to be kinder to myself as I navigate the challenges of everyday life.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Melissa O'Connell: In total, our household made around $6,500 in the past month. I earn a salary from my job in local government, and James has a teaching position at a public school, so our combined income covers most of our expenses. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to keep us comfortable and allow us to contribute to the community in ways that matter to us. I've always believed that financial stability is important, but I also think it's just as vital to live with purpose and intention. I'm grateful for the work we both do, and I feel like we're in a good place financially—especially considering the cost of living in Chicago. I know it's not the same for everyone, but I try to be mindful of how we spend and save, and I feel like we're making it work.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Melissa O'Connell: I've been at my current job for about seven years now, and it's been a journey of growth and learning. One of the biggest benefits of working for the city is the health insurance coverage—it's comprehensive, and it's something I really appreciate, especially with my back issues and the ongoing need for physical therapy. We also get a generous amount of paid time off, which is something I've come to rely on. I used to think that taking time off was a sign of weakness, but now I see it as a necessary part of staying productive and healthy. We get about 20 days of vacation each year, plus sick days and holidays, which gives me the flexibility to recharge when I need to. Another thing I value is the retirement plan the city offers—it's not perfect, but it's a start, and I contribute as much as I can. I also really like the sense of purpose that comes with the job. Even though it can be stressful and politically charged at times, I feel like I'm doing work that matters, and that makes all the difference.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Melissa O'Connell: My relationships at work are pretty much what I'd call collaborative and supportive, though they're not without their challenges. I've been lucky to have a manager, Sarah, who I really respect. She's been in the field for over 20 years and has a deep understanding of the community work we do. She's not just focused on getting things done—she genuinely cares about the people we're trying to help. She's been a great mentor to me, pushing me to think critically and not just follow the status quo. That said, there are times when our goals don't always align, especially when political pressures come into play. But I think that's part of the job—learning how to navigate those tensions while staying true to your values. As for my coworkers, I have a good group of people who I trust and who I can rely on. We've been through a lot together, from late-night meetings to dealing with the frustrations of slow-moving bureaucracy. I think what makes our team strong is that we all share a common purpose, even if we don't always agree on the best way to get there. There are definitely moments of stress and disagreement, but overall, I feel like I'm part of a team that's trying to make a real difference, and that makes all the difference in how I show up every day.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Melissa O'Connell: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's definitely some flexibility depending on the needs of the projects I'm working on. I usually start around 8:30 a.m., and I try to leave by 5:30 p.m., but there are days when I stay late for meetings or finish up some reports. The city job has a standard structure, but I've learned that being adaptable is part of the job. Sometimes, I'll have to attend neighborhood council meetings in the evenings or meet with residents on weekends, which means my hours aren't always the same from week to week. That said, I do appreciate the flexibility—it allows me to be present for the community in ways that matter, even if it means working outside of the typical 9-to-5. I've also found that having a consistent start and end time helps me maintain a work-life balance, which is something I've had to be really intentional about, especially with my health and personal life.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Melissa O'Connell: Overall, I feel pretty stable financially, but I know it's a balancing act. We're not wealthy by any means, but we're not struggling either. I think the key for us has been being intentional with our money—prioritizing what's most important and making sure we're not just surviving, but also living with some sense of security. I've always believed that financial stability is important, but I also think it's just as vital to live with purpose and intention. I'm grateful for the work we both do, and I feel like we're in a good place financially—especially considering the cost of living in Chicago. I know it's not the same for everyone, but I try to be mindful of how we spend and save, and I feel like we're making it work. At the same time, I'm aware that things could change in an instant, which is why I've been trying to build that emergency fund and stay as prepared as I can. It's not about being rich—it's about being ready, and I think that's something I can be proud of.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial situation and work life are intertwined with my overall well-being. Thinking about how my bills fluctuate throughout the year—whether it's due to seasonal changes, unexpected expenses, or personal needs—reminded me of the importance of being flexible and proactive with my budget. It's not always easy to stay on top of everything, especially with the rising costs of living in Chicago, but I've learned that small adjustments and intentional spending can make a big difference. At the same time, thinking about my job and how many hours I work each week made me realize how much I value the balance between work and personal life. I've come to see that my work isn't just about earning a salary—it's about contributing to something meaningful, and that gives me a sense of purpose. I'm grateful for the stability we have, but I also know that it's something I have to keep working at, both financially and emotionally.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Melissa O'Connell: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up, though their jobs were pretty different. My dad worked as a mechanic at a local auto shop, and he was always up early, sometimes before dawn, to get to work. He had a steady job, but it wasn't easy—long hours, not a lot of benefits, and the kind of work that takes a toll on your body. My mom worked part-time at a grocery store, which gave her more flexibility, but it wasn't enough to cover everything. She often had to work double shifts or take on extra hours during the holidays to make ends meet. I remember seeing how hard they both worked, especially during the colder months when the shop was slower and the grocery store had fewer customers. It wasn't always comfortable growing up in a working-class household, but it taught me a lot about resilience, sacrifice, and the value of hard work. I think that's why I ended up choosing a career in community development—because I wanted to help people like them, who are trying to build a better life but don't always have the support or resources they need.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Melissa O'Connell: My dad's job as a mechanic was pretty hands-on—he worked on everything from cars to trucks, fixing engines, replacing parts, and making sure vehicles were safe to drive. He had a small shop in the neighborhood, and he was known for being reliable, even if he wasn't always the most talkative person. His most important duties were diagnosing problems, performing repairs, and making sure customers left with their cars running smoothly. He didn't have a lot of formal training, but he had a natural talent for mechanics and learned most of what he knew through experience and by watching other mechanics work. My mom, on the other hand, worked at a local grocery store, mostly in the produce section. Her job involved restocking shelves, helping customers find what they needed, and making sure the store stayed organized. She had a way of making people feel welcome, even if she was tired after a long shift. Both of them had their own challenges, but they always made sure to put food on the table and give me and my sister the best they could. Looking back, I think their work shaped me in a lot of ways—it showed me the value of hard work, the importance of community, and the kind of resilience that comes from knowing you have to fight for everything you want in life.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Melissa O'Connell: My dad worked at a small, family-owned auto shop on the South Side, and my mom worked at a local grocery store called 'O'Leary's Market.' The shop was run by a few guys who had been in the business for decades, and it was a real neighborhood place—people brought in their cars, and they'd chat with the mechanics while they waited. My dad was one of the lead mechanics there, and he was pretty well-respected for his work. He didn't make a lot of money, but he had a good reputation, and people trusted him. My mom's grocery store was a bit more community-focused too. It wasn't a big chain, and the owners were from the neighborhood, which made it feel like a second home for a lot of people. She worked long hours, but she always made time to talk to customers, and I think that's why people kept coming back. I remember seeing her smile even on her toughest days, and that's something I carry with me to this day—it showed me what it means to be kind and hardworking at the same time.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Melissa O'Connell: A few years from now, I hope I'm still doing the work that feels meaningful—still pushing for affordable housing, supporting small businesses, and being part of the community that raised me. I hope I'm still living in this neighborhood on the North Side, even if it's changed a little, and that I'm still connected to the people who make it feel like home. I hope James and I have started a family by then, and that we're raising kids who understand the importance of kindness, resilience, and fighting for what's right. I also hope I'm healthier, not just physically but mentally, and that I've continued to grow in ways I can't even imagine right now. I don't know exactly what the future holds, but I hope it's filled with purpose, love, and the kind of quiet happiness that comes from knowing you've made a difference, even in small ways.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Melissa O'Connell: What I value the most in my life is connection—connection to the people I love, to the community I've grown up in, and to the work that gives my days meaning. I think it's easy to get caught up in the hustle of everyday life, but what keeps me grounded is knowing that I'm part of something bigger than myself. I value the relationships I've built with James, my family, my friends, and the people I work with. They're the ones who remind me why I do what I do. I also value the sense of purpose that comes from working in community development—knowing that even small actions can create ripples of change. And I value the lessons I've learned from my parents, especially the strength it takes to keep going when things are hard. I think, at the end of the day, what matters most is being present, being kind, and being willing to fight for what's right—not just for myself, but for others who might not have the same voice or resources I do.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how my work and financial situation are deeply intertwined with my sense of stability and purpose. Thinking about my household income, the predictability of my work schedule, and the benefits I receive from my job reminded me of how lucky I am to have a role that not only pays the bills but also allows me to contribute meaningfully to my community. It's easy to take these things for granted, but I've come to appreciate the balance I have—between work and personal life, between financial responsibility and emotional well-being. I've also realized how much my relationships at work matter. Having a supportive manager and coworkers who share my values makes all the difference in how I show up each day. It's not always perfect, but I feel like I'm in a good place, and I'm grateful for the stability and purpose that come with my job.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a deeply reflective experience, reminding me of how much my past, present, and future are intertwined. From my childhood in Chicago, shaped by my parents' hard work and love, to the pivotal decision I made in college that set me on this path, every moment has led me to where I am today. I've come to appreciate the struggles I've faced—whether it was financial challenges, health issues, or the emotional weight of my work in community development—as they've all played a role in shaping who I am. This journey has shown me the importance of purpose, connection, and resilience. I've learned that life isn't always easy, but it's the people, the choices, and the small moments of kindness that make it worth living. I'm grateful for the support of my family, my friends, and my community, and I hope that one day, someone else can look back on their own life and feel the same sense of purpose and gratitude that I do now.
